review_title: RUN ON CALL 24/7 NO SICK TIME AWAY FROM 2-3 DAYS ONLY 10 HOURS OFF AT HOME
pros: OK PAY UNLESS U DON'T HAVE A LIFE
cons: I just started working for CSX back in August every Monday at the CSX REDI Center in ATL they bring in classes of 60 conductors because the overturn rate is over 90% I'm about to quit myself NO SICK TIME ON CALL 6/7 DAYS A WEEK absent attendance policy 80 points Max 7 points per day 10 points for miss call only received 20 points taken off for good attendance after 6 months so u better not get sick or have a family emergency you're only guaranteed 1 day off per week on the extra board none on the pool board they have until 8 p.m. the day before your day off to call you for work SO if they do call cancel all your plans on your day off because you're working now 🤣once u get back home 2 days later they will give you 24 hours off instead of the required 10 hours rest to make up for your day off that u missed but after u get your regular 10 hour rest now u only have just 14 hours of your day off to enjoy 😡and they can call you 2 hours before your day off is over to report exactly at the 24 hour mark they rush us through training because they're so short-handed so majority of new hires are having derails and accidents every day I know a lot of you guys will say you get paid a lot my average annual income for right now if I keep working at CSX will be around 75k but I can work at other jobs and make close to that but with better benefits and less drama & 2 days off per week & paid sick days ONE LAST THING WE DON'T PAID PER HOUR it's BY the JOB/MILES SO THEY WILL KEEP U AT WORK 12 HOURS minimum EVERY DAY ONLY 10 HOURS OFF RIGHT BACK AT WORK TO DO ANOTHER 12 HOURS WE BE SO TIRED & SLEEPY ALL THE TIME AT WORK I'M DONE WITH CSX "labor does not contribute to profits" according to CSX

review_title: Does not listen to employee wishes
pros: Good people on direct teams
cons: CSX has always been a premier employer, however, in the post covid flexible environment they are falling far behind other employers in the Jacksonville and national markets. Employees have been very open about the fact that that would prefer the possibility of hybrid positions but the company has his head in the sand and has made little to no accommodations. Remote positions are offering higher salaries for professionals. Along with the higher salaries, remote employees do not have to pay for gas. Individuals working in the office are indirectly making lower salaries than people working remotely due to gas. Office employees are also losing 1-2 hours a day to commuting which is unnecessary. This amounts to almost a full extra week of work (just in drive time) that we are dedicating to our employer. This has a huge impact on lifestyle. The company should raise salaries to accommodate for this discrepancy or allow more flexibility. At the end of the day, we have less time with our families and less money. Something has to give. It seems they just don’t care and are not listening.

review_title: No Life, No Contract, No Sleep
pros: Decent pay, but no raise in 3+ years - even through being "essential" during Covid .
cons:
They have an awful point/ attendance policy. 
Left in motels away from family days on end.
Personal days can not be taken when needed 
Work 95% of all holidays without holiday pay. 
We go by a board system that should tell us about when we may be called but crew management puts BS times & train schedules in there that we can never judge on how or when we may be called out. Working exhausted - always!
They used to have rules that would allow you to mark off due to weather related incident - your town can make an alert that no one is to be on the road & they still tell you to drive on in. 
You get one set day a week off... It maybe scheduled for Monday but you probably wont get it till Wednesday. 
Work / life balance is non-existent. 
Officials wait & hide in bushes to see if you mess up, they also fly night vision drones to watch you, along with Inward facing cameras on the engines to watch what you do on the engines 
You get placed in bed bug infested hotels.
A good % of Crew management doesn't do their job effectively & talks down to crews. You are responsible for the short comings of the other person on the engines. They screw up You're fired too. 
Don't worry you will always have the work excuse to miss every activity that your children are in, every wedding you're invited to & the funeral of your wife's grandmother bc that's is NoT your immediate family. Get ready to ruin your family life if you don't have a strong backbone together! If you're single, don't have much family to speak of, this is the job for you!

pros: None anymore they have gutted it to nothing if you want to be gone all the time with no compensation apply
cons: Csx doesn’t care about you only the share holders. They run these long trains up to 14000 feet and have no where to park them so you sit on it 12 plus hours every trip then 30 plus in hotel get home for 10 then back out on the same stuff and they want to fire you every chance they get it. Can’t pay us a decent raise but we worked through pandemic with no extra compensation but don’t worry the company made record profits. Constantly have to check your check because they always try to screw you out of something.. if you want extra stress added to your life apply and like a company run by people with out any railroad knowledge then this is the job for you.

review_title: There's a reason for the high turnover
pros:
Benefits and total compensation are some of the best for the Jacksonville area. If you are a townie who just wants a stable job for the next 30 years (or until the next re-org), this is the company for you. If you're a high-performer and free-thinker, then you'll only be happy for a short-time. The lifers openly say they just "drink the Kool-aid" so they can collect a check (or make it to 5 years to lock-in Railroad Retirement). 

From a technology standpoint, CSX does leverage modern methods and technology, but it will vary heavily on your team and manager. They have not actually adopted a true agile mindset across the Technology organization.

The CIO is easy to talk to and open to feedback. She'll actually listen/read what you have to say and get things done.

The overall benefits, as a management employee, like healthcare are great. You get HSA matching and relatively low premiums. There's access to a gym, plus other programs.
cons:
Ever since the Hunter Harrison takeover, CSX has dramatically shifted its focus aware from employees toward the bottom line. Of course a business needs to be profitable, but leadership only cares about big their dividend will be of of their shares, or their end of year bonus. Leadership often uses meaningless jargon to make it seem like not giving employees a raise or reducing bonus potential is actually a good thing. IT leadership specifically is full of conniving individuals lording over their fiefdom. They prefer to play corporate politics, rather than properly leading and mentoring their teams. The business partners have little regard for technology, which strains the relationship when trying to build solutions.

CSX tends to promote individuals to their highest-level of incompetence (Peter Principle). This results in managers and project managers who have no idea how to lead, nor proper understanding of their domain. You can actually leverage this to your advantage as an outside hire. I saw numerous individuals talk their way into technical roles, when they clearly could not do the work. They just delegated their work away and blamed others when things were done incorrectly. That said, certain individuals like this are protected by their bosses and HR. Leadership would rather keep an ineffectual PM/Mgr in place, than admit they made a bad hire. If you follow the ethics process and report issues, as instructed, with evidence, you will be outed and punished for not being a team player.

On the topic of promotion, because there's many incompetent individuals in senior positions, you'll be hard pressed to be promoted. Leadership tends to promote those who they hand-select and groom into loyalty. You'll see certain individuals quickly skip pay bands and positions, while you and your teammates are told you need to follow specific track; that there are no promotions available. If you apply for an internal transfer/promotion, there's a good likelihood that your manager will sandbag your interview if they don't fully condone your team change.

If you're a high-performer, you will be heavily relied upon to carry your team. Yes, you should be a team player, but you should not be expected to cover for senior teammates who consistently drop the ball.

There's a reason IT has such high turnover. There's a reason why the overwhelming majority of my training class left the company. At the end of the day, you are expendable to CSX.

job_title: Digital Communications Manager in Jacksonville, FL
pros: I get to be a teammate to some of the hardest working men and women in the United States. Coming from a different industry, I had little understanding on how important rail is to the U.S. economy. I didn't know how many different skill sets were needed to keep the railroad moving. I ignorantly assumed or generalized that there were conductors, engineers and others that support the rail...but not knowing much more. We have operations in the building and in the field, techies, analysts, sales, marketing, a police department and so many more. I have been fortunate to stand side-by-side with a diverse and fun group of craft employees, managers, and senior leadership that have an unparalleled drive. My colleagues are some of the most proud and passionate people I have ever had the pleasure to worked with. The company itself is always examining new and innovative ways to redefine rail freight and the technologies that support what we do. It's an exciting time to be working here! By the way, the pay is pretty awesome too!
cons: While most have good work-life balance, some teams (at certain times) have more work than the typical 9-to-5ers. That being said, you have to remember that the railroad is running 24-7-365.

review_title: I was a Trainmaster for two years.
pros: The benefits were outstanding. If someone had to work their entire career in the operations portion of CSX, the retirement package is good. They will teach you the basics of a job prior to sending you to the field. Continuity is not a popular word in my opinion because with knowledge comes power and too many people feel the need to hold that power in order to maintain validity.

pros: All good things to say about the company
cons: There are none I love company

pros:
The railroad retirement and pension are great perks, but they benefit you primarily when you retire with the company.  (however, in this day in age, how many people are likely to work for the same company for 30 years?)
The pay is very reasonable here with decent opportunity for bonuses, when the company plans decently enough.
In recent years there seem to be more cross functional collaboration among different parts of the railroad.
cons:
The health insurance has narrowed down to only a consumer-driven health plan, which is great if you are healthy because you may very little each month but have a $1700 deductible if something comes up. A lot of people complained about this, but I didn't have an issue since I was healthy.
The culture is still a little old-school.  Seems to take forever to implement technological enhancements, and I don't mean the kind that get rid of jobs, but the kind that get rid of wasted busy work
There is still room for improvement with diversity.
Everything's about getting the operating ratio lower. It's not "what have you done for me today", but what are you going to do for me tomorrow?
From an operating standpoint, a lot of upper management still has the old militaristic demeanor where they try to bully you to get your numbers up.  
Very short-term goal focused sometimes.
It's a pretty flat organization-  not a lot of layers in the organization, and therefore not a lot of positions to move up to.
They don't do much promoting from within.
Very conservative corporate atmosphere.
Lately, everyone's wondering if they will get laid of the next day.

job_title: Rail Traffic Controller (Train Dispatcher) in Selkirk, NY
pros: Handsome salary. Fast-paced job. No two days are the same. VERY responsible position. You will get creative and use your critical thinking skills on this job!  Generous time off (when you have the time and seniority accrued). Indoor, in a temperature-controlled environment (you're out of the elements).
cons: Ever-changing schedule and shift-work for newer employees (and those with low seniority) - evenings, nights, weekends, and holidays. Stressful job - comparable to an air-traffic-controller, but still much different. Have had many former ATC's claim that there are significantly more variables to consider when compared with train dispatching: fuel, tonnage, train length, outside temperature, track conditions, speed restrictions, signal and grade crossing issues, hours of service, physical characteristics, track maintenance and congestion, too many trains on line-of-road to be adequately handled, and no room in the respective rail yards, until other trains depart ahead. Some have left to pursue ATC. Others (non-ATC) have left to pursue other opportunities (internal and external). This job is not for everyone.

review_title: Treated like garbage, getting paid is a challenge
pros: Pay isn't bad if you can collect your claims
cons:
Have claims in dispute for years. Labor relations declines pay claims for jobs worked and money owed. If you are assigned to a job, pay is no big deal. If you are on a road extraboard, forget about it. They cheat you every chance they get, and if they claim they should not have paid you for a claim it comes out of your check $250 a paycheck. A trip rate of 300 miles is declined and you are paid 130 because your on an extra board, essentially losing $260 each trip. But you moved the train from point A to point B doesn't matter. You have to fight tooth and nail for what is owed to you, and it stays in dispute for years with no interest. Got paid a $200 claim in March 2016 for a dispute from February 2014, of course with 0 interest.
We have 14 people furloughed right now and they are hiring 6 more. People on furlough have been there over a year. 
Installing inward facing cameras in locomotives to spy on you so you sit there with a camera staring you right in the face for 12 hours which can be monitored 24/7 live feed.

pros: Independency, benefits, pay, work environment, promote within
cons: All working conditions, long hours

pros: Pay is ok and work is pretty easy. Benefits are ok but you gotta pay for them all.
cons: On call 24/7, and they will call 24/7!!! Mostly for jobs that your not even qualified to be on. You will have no life, one day off a week. A week day usually. Even if you get to the point you get good seniority as a conductor they will force you to be an engineer and lose it all starting from the bottom again.  If you take a day off, they will threaten you with termination. Only way to take time off is FMLA or calling in sick.  Company ignores union agreements, denies pay and claims due to you. You pay Union dues to a union that doesn't do anything for you. They will leave you in a hotel for 24 hours or more. You could be gone from home for days just to get called back as soon as you wake up and do it all over again. They force safety down your throat but on a daily basis managers tell you to violate the rules and FRA regulations. Any time anything goes wrong the company hangs you. Even when THEY tell you to do something against the rules they still find a way to blame it all on you.

pros: Great benefits, and well protected by the union

review_title: CSX a good place to work, but a bad place for innovation in technology/
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Jacksonville, FL
pros: CSX has a good annual bonus and seems to be thriving in a bad economic environment. When the company is doing well, the annual bonus can be really nice, but can also be non-existent when the company is doing badly. As an Employee, CSX really seems to treat employees with respect and provide an understanding environment. CSX also has many benefits that companies seem to be dropping such as pensions, tuition reimbursement, and medical benefits.
cons:
CSX is a railroad and has an "old school" view of the world. Technology is not retreat with respect and there is no forward thinking strategy. With Technology, CSX is reactionary and does things on whims without any fore thought.

Since we are forced to rush and meet unrealistic expectations of uninformed individuals, most projects lead to downtimes or unmet goals. However, since they are completed ontime and onbudget they are viewed as successful: even though they cost the company more money in the long run.

The work is thusly challenging and frustrating, but with pay and compensation it is very difficult to leave.

pros: Good pay,retirement,and benefits but that's about it.
cons: New management group has ruined this company, employees quitting at all levels.

review_title: A good job until they stopped paying me.
pros: I like the change of places to work. I could be going down to jersey one day, out to boston the next. Every trip, train, engineer, day, and trainee is different. I like being a conductor. Its a good job, always a change of pace. Its a great way to make money. Benefits are awesome and good retirement.
cons: While in the training program for Conductor and engineer we were told by upper level management (System Road Foreman) that there are pay problems.Trainees don't get paid for weeks at a time. Its a known problem in CSX. You can complete everything on your end of submitting your pay and making sure its correct and still your pay would be messed up. I was helping people to fix there pay, because the managers don't know how. And still I didn't get paid because my salary because of how horrible there system is. After not being paid for 3 weeks and complaining to management multiple times about the problem I finally quit CSX and found another job. I was there for 3 years.

review_title: Please start holding your managers accountable
pros: Decent pay, good benfits. More job choices as seniority grows.
cons: Even though you can make up to 100k plus being an engineer or conductor, it is not as good as it seems. You may be on a train 12 hours then go to a motel for up to 16 hours or more. Then get called for 12 more hours on a train back home. The job may pay 300 or so a trip, so thats around 600 for 40 hours being away from home. Management at walmart probaly makes more than that. Also the csx management try as hard as they can from day 1 to fire you. I have been there 8 years and have seen some of the best workers harassed and fired. Usually the managers are out of collage and dont know anything about railroading. It is a hard and dangerous job like it is but it makes it even more stressful knowing there could be someone in the bushes watching you. People ask me, why do you stay there if it is like that? The answer is because once you get use to the money it is hard to leave. Also the hours will suck, but I cannot blame them for that. They tell you up front that this is not a 9-5 job. But they do not tell you that everyday you work for them that they are trying there best to fire you.

pros: Pay and benefits are great
cons: Choose between money and family life

review_title: Excellent benefits, Great pay and job security
job_title: Railroad Special Agent in Atlanta, GA
pros: Extreme amount of freedom and the ability to manage your own time and work. Management is laid back, but will assist you if you need advice. You get a raise every year plus 10% of your annual salary in bonuses there is no maximum top out . You are assigned an unmarked take home vehicle equipped with a police package and company gas card that you drive until you retire or quit. The Railroad industry is investing heavily in green technology and has been around for over 200yrs so job security is solid.  Retirement benefits are great with Railroad retirement, Company pension and medical.
cons:
The only con.....we get paid once a month. It takes some getting used to and a little money managing skills, but you will get use to it after a while.

If you don't like to drive ...don't apply. They give you a vehicle and they expect you to use it a lot.  Driving is essential  in this job so you have to have a good driving record. If you wreck your assigned vehicle in an at fault accident it will be a career suicide and they will take it out of your annual bonus.

review_title: Great Job....IF you can keep it
pros:
Great pay, you can basically write your own check.
Benefits are good.
Retirement--if it holds up--is one of the best you can still get.
Most of the guys you work with are good people.
Easy laid back work. I've worked 10 times harder for half the pay.
cons: Business side sucks as the company can make a billion dollars in profits in a year and they want to lay people off because they didn't make 1.1 billion. Union sucks, no representation because the company has them in their back pocket. Get told on your first day of training you have lucked out in life and landed a career but then get laid off twice in a little over 2 years. If you're not out of your apprenticeship, a journeyman can get laid off 1,000 miles away and come take your job without warning. when they get there they'll escort you off the property like you're a felon or something. luckily my bosses were cool and let me know a couple of days beforehand--which they are NOT supposed to do--to avoid that situation.

review_title: 30 Year Career both hourly and management
pros: The railroad retirement pension is one of the last defined pensions that will allow you a comfortable secure retirement.   If you can go into management, (not operations) you can have a great career.   The pay and benefits are supported by the union rank and file employees.   If you are sharp and willing to work hard, you will be noticed in this political organization.
cons: Railroading operations is a dangerous business that requires dedication to knowledge of your job, equipment and geography.   Your home life will suffer with being on call and not be able to plan in train service and you could be found civilly liable for a train accident.  Railroads are para-military organizations and with lots of government, union and company rules.  You will get yourself on the wrong side of the rules and there will be consequences.   Working conditions in the field can be horrid.

review_title: A lot of games... Not for professionals
pros: If you like working outdoors there is plenty of that.  (Note: if you don't like working outdoors, just add this and only real "pro" to the exceedingly long list of cons.
cons:
There are far too many cons to this industry, company, and job to list in this space.  So I will highlight a few that had a profound impact on my experience:
1) Functional silos - ensuring the movement of tons of freight across your territiory safely and on time while working cross functionally is a pipe dream
2) Corporate culture - cultivated by fear and frat house traditions
3) Operational leadership- leaders in the field do not pocess the skills and abilities to manage employees or make sound buisness decisions
4) Double talk - status quo is not only expected its how you survive
5) "People make the difference" - the biggest myth at CSX is that you matter to the organization, in reality you and your opinions are meaningless and any attempt to affect change through postive contribution is futile.  You are a number... take your geographical assignment, ask no questions and pray no one gets injured during your "watch."

pros:
Great compensation and benefits
Wonderful cafeteria, starbucks coffee and on-site gym
Free downtown parking
River views
cons: At least for me, there seems to be a real downturn in development and employee engagement. The atmosphere is tense, and has been for the last 2 years. We've been through a lot of upheaval, but management only barely acknowledges the struggles before asking us to carry more. It's stressful and I can see how anyone who survived the last few rounds of heavy cuts could just be exhausted now. We're all "doing more with less" which seems to be the new company motto. Barely scraping by each quarter is no way to build a loyal workforce. The culture of this organization is non-existent compared to when I started 6 years ago. We never even hear from the new CEO, Jim Foote, except for when he hires new people to his team. Our old CEO, Michael Ward, gave a state-of-the-railroad address every Friday morning and our previous executive team would hold quarterly townhalls to talk with everyone and answer questions directly. I don't even know who the upper management is anymore, it changes so frequently.

review_title: Management only concerned with moving to the top.
pros: $30.00 an hour and great insurance. I can't really think of a lot of good things to say about CSX. You can be an idiot and still get hired.
cons:
If hired, you will be placed on second shift or cat eye until your retirement and you will have Wednesday and Thursday off. You will never see daylight.
Management knows nothing about locomotives. The shop where I work is more concerned with catching you doing something wrong, so they can charge you or better yet, walk you off of the property.
The union, "IAM", is worthless. You pay them to hold a spot on the overtime board.
The electrical craft is catered to by management. All other crafts are made to do each others work.
I've never worked around so many lazy people in my life. 
Management forces overtime.
Management doesn't care if you repair the locomotive as long as you sign it off in the computer.
Production over safety is the norm. Don't believe the safety hype.
Management trying to make seniority system wide. The system is huge. Maine to Florida.

review_title: If you want to have no life, then become a Conductor.
pros: For those with only limited education i.e. “High School Degree” great pay and benefits. Glassdoor wants at least twenty words for pros, so if you enjoy working outside in snow, rain, freezing temperatures, freezing rain, thunderstorms for 12 hours, this is your job. They might let you come inside due to a hurricane or tornado, just depends on if they need to knock the signal down to show the train departed the yard on time.
cons: A Conductor has no life, do not get married, don’t have a family. You have “ No Life” except being on call 24/7. Think you get a regular day off, think again, they can work you right into your schedule off day. About 90% of the engineers you will work with are great, love to here the crew call tell me I’m working with one of them. Well the other 10% are the ones who don’t care, break the rules and can be very difficult to work with. There’s some weird old head engineers out there "Well that’s how we done it 20 years ago" Usually you will end up tolerating most engineers, but there will be a few you will hate to work with.

review_title: If you want to have no life, then become a Conductor.
pros: For those with only limited education i.e. “High School Degree” great pay and benefits. Glassdoor wants at least twenty words for pros, so if you enjoy working outside in snow, rain, freezing temperatures, freezing rain, thunderstorms for 12 hours, this is your job. pros: The pay is better than average
cons: the lifestyle is not good.

review_title: Definitely pays your current bills, plus your future divorce attorney and child support
pros: It's a union position---it's one of the best paying jobs you'll be able to find without a technical degree/Masters/PhD.  Gratifying if you enjoy working outside or love trains (of course).
cons: Schedule, Schedule, Schedule. 24 hr call schedules sound manageable until you're living with it day to day.  It's exhausting/frustrating to answer all of life's questions with "I might have to work." It's difficult to plan anything in advance. This is not a career for somebody with young children or somebody who likes to ...have a life.  You schedule has potential to improve once you build seniority, but, it could be a decade before you have a scheduled, same shift, 5 day a week job. Seriously, the schedule is brutal. Also beware hiring blitzes---the railroads are notoriously bad about hiring a ton of people at a time, then realizing their projected needs were incorrect and gradually (or not) laying all those people off.

review_title: Met you at Black Enterprise Conference, would they be proud of you?
pros: The company offers a great medical benefits package.  As for leadership, most races outside of the Caucasian race are afraid to be a part of the management program prior to gaining seniority in some other trade,  because of the Company's mistrust and track record.
cons: Females are totally ostracized, African American's are totally unwelcomed , male African Americans are tolerated and are very non-vocal in an effort to maintain their jobs.  Many will not pursue training and those that have tell the stories of being passed over and over even though they've exceeded the training, education, and qualifications required.

review_title: Company only worried about one thing, utilizing assets
pros: Benefits are decent. Pay is above average,
cons: There are quite a few negatives that have happened at csx in the last few decades. Management has changed from a culture of working with people to a structure of trying to force their will at every turn. There is near zero employee engagement at any level of the structure these days. People once went above and beyond. There are only three ways to motivate any employee in any job. Pay. Time. Opportunity. The pay is decent but if you are a union employee, they refuse to collow their agreements. Time was one of the only motivators we had. They'd let you leave early if you got your work finished. Now? No leaving early and no time off. We are threatened weekly with a new notice or mailing to our homes about taking any time off. And opportunities have disappeared as the hedge fund cut and cut and cut.

review_title: CSX is a good place for a long-term career
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Jacksonville, FL
pros: The pay is good, as are benefits.  Growth opportunities are provided, and can enable a person to work in multiple different departments during a career with the company. Employees are encouraged to develop themselves, both technically and as regards management ability.  Bonus program has paid well the last few years, even in a down economy.
cons: Corporate culture is always a challenge, navigating the politics.  Overtime is expected to be worked without compensation, though some managers make efforts to provide balancing time off for their people. There is no clear promotion path for many positions, and this encourages employees to move and take new a new job in a different department in order to advance.  Bonus distribution is not as objective as I would like, and requires immediate management to negotiate the money for their direct reports.

job_title: Inter-modal Cust Operations in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Pay ranks high, at least for jobs in Florida. Training, people, Corp mission statement all seem great - in the beginning.
cons: Politics as usual. You are expected to take some sort of initiating abuse from some of the long time co-workers = peers. This perspective is in "Management" - Non-Union position. Depending on which Regional Team you're lucky or unlucky enough to be placed in. My experience was not good as management tolerated some employees to be unprofessional, rude, and even abusive to new employees trying to learn the antiquated computer systems. I had zero support during very stressful time. Phone calls were nonstop. Service failures were plentiful. Have nerves of steel, love call center and customer complaints, and thrive in politics and favoritism, then this is the dream job for you!

review_title: While an active employee, over all good
pros: Pay, benefits, education opportunity, diversity
cons:
If you retired after 2003, the company executives decided to stick our insurance premiums on our backs.
They failed to tell us retiring boomers that once a $15,000 ceiling was crossed (per family) we'd carry the burden of our insurance cost. We were never told this during our retirement seminars. Even those who retired in the summer of 2011 were not told. Our insurance premiums increased by 94% for 2012. This had the effect of wiping out our management pensions. That's the appreciation we received for acheiving the position of management. Forty years as an employee and twenty as management. That's a big thanks. A multi billion dollar industry is just too cheap to help us for five years until we reach medicare age. CSX never adjusted the ceiling they set in 2003, how's that for planning?

review_title: They ask more than you can possibly give regardless of your work ethic. Very poor.
pros: Experience, responsibility and an opportunity to lead a fortune 250 company. Networking is excellent and relationships with other employees flourish due to the extended hours.
cons:
Absolutely no work life balance whatsoever. Give, give and give is what you will do as this organizations motto is take, take and take. 

Family, personal and professional relationships are consistently strained due to the incredible dedication that is expected from all CSX employees. 

After years of dedicated service the treatment of employees  has not improved at all. 
Harassment is not allowed but threats of firing employees happens daily and is common in public forums. 

Very unprofessional approach to development and advancement. 

This review is not by a bitter ex employee but rather by one that has survived all of the cuts and watched from the sidelines as many of my friends have been treated horribly and with zero respect. To say that I'm appalled is an understatement. I am actively trying to find another job and would hesitate to recommend this organization to an enemy.

pros: Benefits and Pay are about it. It's an easy job that is not physically demanding. Union craft position.
cons: You're not paid for what you do nor how well you do it, you're paid for the inconvenience of being "On Call".  Until you've about 10-15 years under your belt, don't expect any regularity in your work schedule. As a side note if you have a family, and don't have to make $100k per year stay away cause it's not worth it. Union Craft Position

pros: Many opportunities to get trips and make money if you are okay with working conditions.  Room to grow professionally if you are willing to relocate.
cons: While many other jobs within CSX will have structured hours and time off.  Freight conductor is not one of them.  DO NOT expect to know when you will have time off.  When it comes, expect using time to get much needed rest.  Time between trips is spent resting catching up from last trip and getting ready for next.  After mandatory 10 hour rest, wait for next call.  Call could come immediately or a day later.  Makes it very hard to plan day/sleep patterns to arrive for next trip bright eyed and bushy tailed.  Safety stressed but many find it confusing when standards are broken by management to get job done but then enforced when convenient.  Very poor Union vs Management environment.

review_title: AVOID CSX NORTH JERSEY AT ALL COSTS FOR THEY'LL DESTROY YOUR LIVELIHOOD, FAMILY, AND STABILITY.
pros: Great men to work with on or around the trains. The pay isn't what you'd want it to be but does take of what you need it to so long as you remain working. No matter your background and views, as long as you know your business (work) you'll be good amongst your co-workers.
cons:
The worst management there is to mankind. Extremely racist without the bluntness of it.
They are more engaged in setting you up to fire or suspend you than actually doing what it is necessary in running the company as it should be. There was one guy who was superintendent. He went from that to a Trainmaster then to Yardmaster. He's super terrible even at that job. If management has a vendetta against you, they'll do anything and everything, even illegal things, to ensure you no longer work there. The work environment and conditions force you to worry more about engaging with management than to focus on your duties.

job_title: Locomotive Engineer and Conductor in Indianapolis, IN
pros: Good pay and benefits. Nice pension. The railroad is now a stable industry for the first time in decades. Also, lots of improvement to the track structure this year - better late than never!
cons:
It takes years to acquire enough seniority to hold a regular job. But worst of all, labor-management relations are awful. CSXT was certainly too lenient in previous generations, but it is now overly strict, to the point of sheer lunacy. Managers are required to find fault and put employees into formal investigations over the smallest things, or they can forget about being promoted. I can't imagine how much money is lost because management is sucking the initiative out of good workers. The management training program turns bright young men into scared, arrogant fools.

Lastly, positions are cut and rationalized before the technology to do so is perfected, often resulting in collisions, damage and injuries.

review_title: union are weak dont have your back
pros: great pention benifits suck now pay great
cons: work schedule no sick time bosses are clueless

review_title: Great pay but I work long hours, not for evreryboby.
pros: Csx is a leader in the transportation industry. I am well paid and over the years have been able to establish a very comfortable lifestyle. This is a very stable company that provides an environmantally friendly necessary service.
cons: Long hours in the operations positions. I sense that older managers tend to be overlooked for key promotions that seem to be handed to young people with marginal experience. Also, the "good old boy " network is alive and thrives with this company. My overall  impression is that Senior management want "yes men" promoted to key positions and discount mangers who are either older or not in lock step with their views..

pros:
Pay and other benefits are negotiated by Union contract. 
better that working at mcdonalds.
cons: Pay and other benefits are negotiated by Union contract. Guilty until you prove yourself innocent of charges. Good ole boy system.  You will be nothing nut a number to the company and a pay increase will cause union dues and insurance cost to rise. no matching 401K for contract employees. Insurance cost have risen from no out of pocket and $15 co-pays to $240 per mo. $2k deductible and $75 co-pays in 8 years. with only aa $3 per hour rise. I have almost 20 years invested and though the company's profits continue to rise the moral of the people who are doing the construction and maintenance is at an all time low. There was a time in my career i looked forward to going to work.

pros: CSX has many opportunities for all areas in business as well as in craft trades. There are several companies under the CSX Corporate umbrella. CSX provides excellent training and support to further your knowledge base and prepare you for future responsibilities and compensation. The culture is excellent for anyone wanting to advance in their careers. Excellent benefits and reward/recognition programs as well as advancement opportunities. Salaries are very competitive with other similar industries. The five core values of the company are taken seriously and our reputation is impeccable. The executive team provides innovative leadership. Communications are timely and transparent. You control your future by participating in training and desire to do a good job. CSX, a great place to work and grow.
cons: Cons are very few. As with any large corporation, there is a bureaucracy. This is softened by the quick response to needs by the differing departments.

job_title: IT Project Manager in Jacksonville, FL
pros: CSX's new executive team has improved the company's operating ratio significantly, thus causing a huge uptick in CSX's stock price. So, if you own their stock...you are happy. Lol. Also, Jim Foote may be the company's next CEO. If that happens, that's a positive thing, because he is more employee-focused than Hunter Harrison.
cons: Fear-based environment. No job security. A bully for a CEO who appears to only care about himself and Wall Street investors - not people.

pros: They are a contributor to railroad retirement but beyond that  have nothing for them personally. If you are able to make the same money in another career then do so and invest yourself in you own retirement.
cons: Retaliatory and vindictive toward labor. The newest company wide trend is the ramping up of their aggression toward the transportation crews and a new willingness to forsake the customer in order to lower wage commitments and make life more uncomfortable for the work force. If you are greedy at any cost it may be for you but as a man of strong moral values I am looking for an exit strategy. Even at 96K/yr I can not tolerate being abused like this.

pros: Great pay and benefits for new employees. Training is extensive as you spend several months shadowing other Trainmasters or taking exams in the Atlanta office.
cons: The job can be really good or really bad depending on who you are paired to train under. Unfortunately I got one of the worst. Work-life balance was nonexistent. In the first few minutes after being placed in a terminal, I usually worked 12 nights on, 2 nights off, for about 13-17 hours a day. I was fresh out of college so I thought this was the norm based on the great pay in comparison to many of my college peers.

review_title: CSX provides a stable organization dedicated to continuous improvement with moments of challenges and years of rewards.
pros: The benefits of working here have been safety mindset, customer focus (new), developmental programs, tuition re-imbursement, railroad retirement, community involvement, great health benefits and the opportunity to work in challenging jobs.
cons: Most of the challenges come from a results driven culture, where diversity hasn't always been a priority. Change in leadership happens often. The business flows with the economy sometimes resulting in furloughs and layoffs. Union agreements govern a large majority of the work and sometimes limits options for increasing production. The work hours for our field jobs can be challenging for employees with families.

review_title: Joining pay is less compared with other companies but will work out good after staying for more than 5 years.
pros: Good work environment. Year end bonus, Flexible timings those who work in Technology and long term retirement benefits.
cons: The pay depends on what field or technology you are working. Initial joining pay will be less compared with other companies. It increases 2 to 3 percent every year. The company offers good bonus every year but again it depends on company profits and individual performance. Do not depend on bonus. Also there is a TCU agency fee that some employees needs to pay monthly and it depends on percentage of salary. That will come around 70 to 100 dollars per month after tax money. Company does not offer promotions automatically depending on work experience. Need to look for job postings and apply.

review_title: CSX,  not the best,  not the worst. Depends who your management is mostly.
job_title: Freight Conductor in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Very good pay,  and benefits 

Low education requirements

Substantial upward mobility
cons:
Management can ruin your career over the slightest issue if they don't like you

Dangerous work

8-12 hr shifts,  no more no less

Until you get seniority,  you basically have no consistent working schedule,  and are always on call. 

Hard to make plans

review_title: Want to give up your life?  Work at CSX
pros:
-Pay is good for the area, so if you want to work in Jacksonville then it's the best option.
-If you are reasonably intelligent, motivated, ambitious, and young, then there are lots of opportunities to advance.
cons:
- Pay isn't as great when you look at cities with similar cost of living.
- The demand long hours, and vacation time is slow to accrue.
- They value people who have worked in the field the highest, even if they don't know how to manage people.
- They say they like diversity, but it depends.  If you are female or African American, then they will do their best to make you feel welcome.  If you are Indian or Asian, you should probably look for another company (and another city).

pros: Not the hardest work I’ve ever done. Most of the people are awesome to work with. The pay is good sometimes.
cons: Trainmen  & Engineer are treated like the scum of the earth and we’re the one on call all the time and away from home with no schedule only one held accountable for anything that happens on the railroad. The pay like I said was good sometimes the problem is on legitimate claims on Work they want deny them or pay what they want to pay day by day.

pros:
Get paid good money without a college degree.
Good coworkers. Co-workers have a family type bond.
You can start from the ground and move up in the company.
Benefits are good.
cons:
The pay is good, but you're selling your social life for an easy buck.
Co-workers become like family because you spend more time with coworkers than your family.
If you have a college degree and no nothing about the railroad you can move up and be a boss. This is a pro and con depending on your point of view. While people that have years of railroad knowledge and experience get left behind because of the BS charges on their work history or they don't know the right people. 
Benefits are good, but it's not cheap working for the railroad. Benefits, union dues, run off insurance adds up.

pros: Decent pay for undertaken responsibilty.
cons: How much time do you have? Union job that behaves just like one. The useless political brown nosers get to skate, the scumbags get defense from the union(s), and the ambitious and motivated get the shaft. Management has zero accountability for their actions and they know it. The agreement rules all, especially when it's nonsensical and assinine, and the litigatory system is marsupial to say the least. General attitude in the place was garbage, and your "brothers" exert more effort avoiding remedial tasks than it would require to exceed expectations exponentially. Alliteration aside, it was literally the worst job I've ever had because of the people. If you're slimy, unmotivated, overweight, and have the attitude, wit, and intellect of an inflamed herpe, THIS is the job for you!

pros: The initial pay is decent; just don't divide your pay by the hours you work.  If you do, you'll likely cry and wonder why you ever went to college.
cons: I don't have the words to adequately describe the pervasiveness of incompetence that plagues this company.  It's maddening to work with and incredibly time consuming.  Virtually every aspect of working here is a "con".  Don't consider employment with CSX unless you're in such dire need of money that you are on the brink of homelessness...and I'd bet that if hired, you'll look back and question whether or not its better to be homeless, or an employee of this company.  Yes.  It's that bad here.

pros: Pay can be good some time, health benefits. But all that is slowly getting worse due to the company changing our contract and the union just standing by doing nothing.
cons: Work life balance, hardly any time at home to be father or husband. Management can't be trusted, all they care about is stock price going up by any means necessary.  Work environment is always negative, and no sort of real ethics in this company. Pay union dues only for company to disregard contract and union does nothing.

review_title: CSX, where your just a number
pros: Railroad retirement is the only good reason to work for csx if your a Union Employee
cons: on call type work, no days off unless you can use a personal leave day or daily vacation day which the company can remove or deny at any time, stay in motels hours away from home 12 hours to 48 hours waiting on trains,  you will miss important life events and the company will not let you off for them,  no sic days off, no comp time off, etc.  You can and will be fired for any rule violations until you can have a formal hearing, the company is 99 percent going to win. Union does a horrible job negotiating contracts. Company violates your union negotiated contract daily and union does nothing about it..

review_title: CSX, where your just a number
pros: Railroad retirement is the only good reason to work for csx if your a Union Employee
cons: on call type work, no days off unless you can use a personal leave day or daily vacation day which the company can remove or deny at any time, stay in motels hours away from home 12 hours to 48 hours waiting on trains,  you will miss important life events and the company will not let you off for them,  no sic days off, no comp time off, etc.  You can and will be fired for any rule violations until you can have a formal hearing, the company is 99 percent going to win. Union does a horrible job negotiating contracts. Company violates your union negotiated contract daily and union does nothing about it..

review_title: Was a great company if you worked in Jacksonville
pros: In general, the company took care of the employees.   They paid well, good bonuses when the company was doing well and decent benefits.    Most of this will likely remain with the new management team.
cons: EHH has a history of paying well but working people very hard.  He also cuts people that he doesn't think is needed.  Lots of senior people are now gone and a lot of knowledge too.   This will cause challenges as well as opportunity to those willing to fight for it.

pros: Pay was on track to be more competitive and I do feel like the company really cared about your safety
cons: Where do I begin, they placed stickers on back of the trucks (how's my driving) and no matter what if someone called the number u were guilty I worked in a small town and people are jealous if they know u are doing well for yourself so they wood call and lie about my driving I wouldn't even be in the area and yet csx would believe the crap they were fed, my work ethic was never questioned huh makes no sense does it, lousy management LOUSY

review_title: Above average compensation/benefits requiring below average lifestyle
pros: Compensation and benefits are on par with companies of the same industry.   Professional development opportunities are available, if desired.  Opportunities for career advancement and numerous locales across the East coast.  Employee health care costs are still below average despite recent rise.  Company matches first first 6% if employee contributions to 401k.  Plus, employees can contribute up to 50% of their salary.
cons: Training process for new hires in the field needs improving.  Also, oversight of on the job training MUST be improved.  Money is spent spent on rail infrastructure, but employee on duty locations and yardmaster towers are sorely neglected.  Employees involved in operations subjected to sometimes severe work schedule.

pros: The pay and tuition reimbursement up to $3500, decent benefits. Seniority and the union, it's honestly hard for me to come up with anything else that I see as a positive.
cons: Very poor management, inability to move up in the company unless you are in with the right people regardless of education and abilities. Employees are not treated as assets or positives for the company and everyone mostly stays for the pay. Intimidation and good ol boy network is very strong here. There is no incentives to think  outside the box status quo is what's expected and do not attempt to challenge long standing procedure's for lest you be accused of not being a team player. I work here currently but I desire to be challenged and promoted. If you desire higher than normal pay and not to be challenged in regards to your personal and professional development this is the place for you.

review_title: GREAT OPPORTUNITY FOR PROFESSIONALS, AVERAGE EMPLOYEES WILL NOT SURVIVE
job_title: Human Resources Professional in Jacksonville, FL
pros: All compensation programs, including, basic pay, railroad retirement, bonus, 401K match.  Smart connected coworkers, willing to help with anything, safety focused at every level, workload is extreme where you must be at your best every day, professional dress, Senior management are easy to talk with.
cons: Mangers take EVERY LITTLE error and mistake and blow it out of proportion.  They spend 99% of the feedback time on the 1 % of mistakes.  They spend 1% of the feedback time on the 99% positives.  Dont worry about what other supervisors think about your employee.

pros: Money and benefits were really good. Most of the peers were really helpful and easy to get along with.
cons: Work schedule is horrible. Economy is slow right now for the rail road. A lot of great people were furloughed and have no idea when they will be called back to work. With the economy so slow right now, the company is looking to fire anyone and everyone. You never feel that you or your job is safe.

pros: Good pay, excellent training, great benefits.
cons: Little or no family life, no upward mobility, glass ceiling for minorities( look at UPPER management), Very stressful( ever heard of "run-off insurance"?). Benefits come thru Union/ you must belong to a Union. Constant testing and evaluation. Somewhat dangerous, easy to get killed or dismembered on the ground as a conductor. Very adversarial relation with management who must "test" and have a percentage of "failures" resulting in punishment (usually time off without pay).

pros: Good pay and benefits.  Opportunities for advancement vary depending on which department you work for.
cons: Serious disjoint between management and craft people.  Craft people are subject to Railroad operating rules and punishment for deviation from the rules is often times exaggeratted.   Management is always looking to blame as opposed to identifying root causes.  If, for example, 70% of your workforce is in some way violating rules, don't you think something may be wrong with the training program?  Or maybe the workers are overloaded?  Maybe they aren't getting proper rest.  Please, look at the root cause instead of assuming everyone, who is human is, deliberately trying to undermine the company that they work for.

pros: Compensation and Benefits Package is good. There is opportunity to grow and develop, however the time and effort put into the company to get to that point may be extreme.
cons: There is not near enough family time and the workplace is full of negativity. It is a good place to make money, however the sacrifices that must be given up in order to make that money may not be worth it to all.

pros: CSX will work you. Being a conductor is not extremely difficult, but you have to pay attention to detail. Pay is good overtime is almost a daily thing and the benefits are some of the best you can find today. Keep this in mind, the Railroad has been around for a hundred years, follow the rules and just show up on time and do as you are asked to do and CSX will put money in your pocket.
cons: It's a transportation company 24/7. If you work as a conductor or engineer you will live your life being on call. The shifts are 12 hours and sometimes you will work longer. The Railroad is not for people who can't grind out hours. Honestly I don't have any cons, I enjoy it. Some of the managers are not the best, they are supervisors and not leaders

pros: The pay is very good. The system is workable so that if you and a union buddy cooperate you can manage to get specific days off.
cons: You have no social life. Sometimes you don't even have a home life. Extremely combative environment between union and management. The entire system is designed to get their employees in trouble. They do whatever they want and do not care about their employees at all.  Management has no clue how to run a railroad. They openly acknowledge that they're ignoring what the customers want so they can fudge their numbers and try to appease the stock owners.

pros: Pay is very good. Benefits are good. Work week can be long, weekends included. Holiday too, especially if you support a location that works 24/7. Generally given what is needed to complete the job, but this is changing. Company is going through a draw down.
cons: Company leads from Jacksonville. Doesn't understand what is going on in the field. Customers can be brutal, no accountability. Communication is terrible. Morale is very low since the cuts have started. People do not know if they will have a job. Very difficult to move up, or move to a different location. Management has no interest in your career, want you to stay where you are so they do not have to do anything.

pros: An idiot can get hired... it's obvious when you work there.  This is one of the Pros.   All idiots apply to CSX you will be loved. ..
cons: If you like working 16hr shifts or 12hr shifts and off on mon and tuesds for the next 20 years then this is the place for you.  Don't believe the Safety nonsense they preach..it's bs.   Work someone 16hr then tell them to be safe.  If your tired your fired... true statement!!!  If you think csx = God then this the place for you.  Arrogance in abundance... wasted years of my life fooling with company.  Don't believe me, try it for yourself... do some research for yourself... lay offs everywhere.   Use to be a good company. ...  POOR WORK ENVIRONMENT PLUS TERRIBLE TERRIBLE COMMUNICATION  = CSX.  I hope this company gets better or collapse like all the rest who thought they were untouchable...

pros: The pay, beneifits, and retirement are great, no college education required, free health and wellness programs, great comradarie among co-workers.
cons: No family life, on call 24/7 365 days a year, being laid off for extended periods. Managers are now hired out of college, instead of coming up through the ranks. They have no knowledge of the operations, equipment, or personal they are required to supervise. Constant fear of losing your job over small rules infractions. Pay raises are not keeping up with inflation. After 6 months of training, you have all the responsibilities of a 5+ years conductor at 80% of the pay.

pros: no expectation of high performance no education required, just coast until retirement, decent pay, some modest union protection, usually friendly co-workers, good job for RR fans, ideal employee was CPA, spent 2 years as conductor / railfan, then got real job with IRS, also retired marine, had military pension, fire proof, been to Afganistan, when higher management (no college, no military, nepotism, worthless) tried to bully him it failed. Military friendly company .
cons: average pay considering hours, nepotism, tuition reimbursement effectively denied to field employees harsh attendance policy, declining health benefits and worthless dental, suggestions / improvements met with hostility, frequent layoffs and punishments, weird hours and schedules mean obesity, alcoholism, divorce are standard features, . lower management treated like dogs, and pass that on to troops. JAX culture and jobs totally different world, no field opportunities to help community, ,

review_title: Best job I ever had--and they took it away.
pros: The pay is off the charts for what you are required to do and the minimal experience you need. The people you work with are great for the most part. Most benefits are above average.
cons: Lay offs and downsizing in every department except IT. If you see a job posting outside of IT that means that they have either cut or run everyone else in that job off. Current CEO is restructuring how American rail runs, and it isn't working. Customers and Government agencies can't even get a clear picture of what is going on.

job_title: Systems Administrator I in Jacksonville, FL
pros: I love my work at CSX.  The work in the IT department is both challenging and rewarding.  I have the opportunity to work on projects in other departments and in other areas of IT.  I also really enjoy the people I work with, which makes a huge difference for me.  The company shows in many ways that it is concerned about me, my family, and the community.  That's important to me and it's something that I can stand behind.
cons: There are plenty of jobs that I'm interested in, but most of them are in Jacksonville, FL.  While I'm fine with living in Jacksonville, the opportunities to relocate are not great.

pros: Very good pay and benefits. Safety is first at CSX, I have been empowered to make decisions about safety and how to preform my job. I have worked at CSX for 11 years and probably will retire from here. Overall its a good place to work.
cons: No path for advancement for craft or hourly employees. The company seems to want t o hire outside the company for management. They hire them at a low wage and they have no railroad experience. Because of that, we have a lot of turnover in field managers. The company is going through a lot of restructuring right now, lots of lay offs and management cut backs despite record profits. They just announced 1000 management lay offs and I expect to see more lays offs soon.

review_title: If you want respect or time with your family, look elsewhere.
pros: Decent pay - health benefits - railroad retirement
cons: Long hours - Time away from family - no respect from management - hassled every time you need a day off - csx believes that the rr is more important than your family.

review_title: An evolving culture takes a step backward
job_title: Sales & Marketing Executive in Jacksonville, FL
pros: In recent years, CSX had developed a positive culture that balanced the needs of all stakeholders, including employees, shareholders, regulators and communities under a long standing executive team.  A tremendous amount of growth and development for all involved, while recognizing that the results mattered and everyone was held accountable.
cons: New management team, backed by a hedge fund, has reversed all the positive momentum build over the last 2-3 years.  Now, the entire focus is on bottom line impact for shareholders at the expense of employees and all other constituencies.

job_title: Engineering Department Manager in Eastern Heights, NC
pros: Benefits of retirement if able to make it that far in new regime's plan. There are still a lot of good people working for the company but they seem to be disappearing at alarming rates as those in charge don't care about covering anyone's job but their own
cons: Management cares only about covering their own tails, even at the expense of lower tiered managers. There is no accountability among those managers as they continue to implement various changes that go against any and all collective bargaining agreements. There is no safety program as is evident by the constantly increasing injuries and accidents. They tell you to preach safety, just not on any call or meeting or anything else where employee engagements can be held. Safety is rules compliance yet they have removed or changed so many rules that were safety oriented. And lastly, again, upper management will never hold themselves accountable if they can throw any lower level manager under the train instead.

pros: Company pay, benefits, and bonus potential are greater than most Fortune 250 companies.
cons: The current corporate culture is toxic as the company is continuing to look to reduce headcount in anyway possible. This has created a stiff culture of political posturing and deceit. In addition to the cultural issues, there is little to no work/life balance. There is a cost to the high salary and good benefits. Many employees complain that they don't get to spend the extra money they are earning because they are "on-duty" 24/7.

review_title: not what its hyped up to be
pros: money and benefits are pretty good for a job that requires no education. The company is ran like the government so you don't work to hard.
cons: You are part of a union and can be bumped out of your job allot. You never know from one day to the next if the company will cut a job off and its up to you to find a place to go and this can be anywhere since they are so spread out. I have moved twice with the company so far and cam in the other day and they cut my job off again.  Also on call 24/7 and the phone rings off the hook.

review_title: CSX is a great company to work for.  It is definitely "How Tomorrow Moves".  I absolutely love working for CSX.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Jacksonville, FL
pros: CSX is like a family.  We care about each other.  The work is interesting and challenging.  It is relatively easy to balance the work life with family life.  The benefit, salary and bonus are awesome!!!
cons: Headquarters in in a city that is riddled with crime, minimal cultural events - not an exciting place to live.  The commute into downtown is not appealing.  The company's stance on safety was not reflected in location selection.

review_title: CSX is a big bureaucracy but the company culture is friendly and employees generally want to do the right thing.
job_title: Sales and Marketing Manager in Jacksonville, FL
pros: The work and the goals are always challenging.  You are part of a prestigious company that is always trying to improve.  The mission - to help industrial America move its freight by rail - is important and an integral part of the US economy.  Great benefits with a pension and an entirely separate, well-funded, retirement system.
cons: Big bureaucracy - often hard to get things done.  Union-influenced culture (but not as much as it used to be).  Some employees are comfortable with mediocrity.  Silo mentality in the different departments.

pros: It helped me get my next job.   That is really it
cons: Leadership is a neanderthal approach.   You are expected to be unethical to achieve "the numbers" if that's what it takes.   Be prepared to be thrown under the bus early and often.   Little known secret:   You manager does not have to allow you the benefits promised from HR during orientation.   You cannot move within the company without your manager "releasing" you - regardless of what HR desires.   Long hours, low-ball pay and they DO NOT CARE about your family life and will tell you this to your face.  Avoid Avoid Avoid.

job_title: Human Resource Analytics in Jacksonville, FL
pros: There's plenty of jobs to apply for.  Work-life balance is good for the office type jobs.  Comp and benefits are good.
cons: Not so much diversity in the workplace. Its a glass ceiling for minority women regarding promotions. The promotions are based on who you know, if they like you, and whether you fit the corporate color.  They encourage you to speak up but concerns or issues but be prepare see that your career is at a halt. Bad behaviors are rewarded. Inconsistent performance management. I've been in both union and management positions. If it was up to me, I rather work in a union position that makes more money than managers and less of the bureaucracy.

pros: I'm really having a hard time coming up with pros. I guess average pay with good benefits. Room for advancement if you have/get a college degree.
cons: Poor managers that expect way too much, while they play on their phones. Terrible people. I have NEVER met people like people that work for CSX. It is unbelievable how mean, shallow and rude most employees are. Work hours suck if you have a family or until you get like 10 years seniority. I can go on for days but I'll spare you the complaining and end here.

pros: Pay and benefits for the required education required
cons: CSX transportation is purchasing your life, crew callers are disrespectful and rude after waking your entire family up in the middle of the night, company culture is horrible, lack of sleep, not knowing when to sleep or when you will be required to work, too many rules, and it is the only place that I have ever worked that you need to purchase insurance for when you will be fired.

pros: Good pay, pension, 401k. Many great co-workers overall. New CEO has an opportunity to make it better overall.
cons: You pay a lot for your pension. 401k not matching. New CEO has been known for cutting many jobs. Shift work. Get used to being a zombie.

pros: The paycheck and the benefits. There is never a boring day at the railroad.
cons: The work/life balance. The harassment and being micro managed by management.

review_title: CSX Technology - A Good Place to Work
job_title: Senior Systems Administrator in Jacksonville, FL
pros:
Multiple Top 100 Places to Work Award
Benefits
Pay / Bonuses
People
Challenges
cons:
Subjective Performance and Development Review System
Little opportunity to cross-train for different skills

review_title: Terrible company to work for - they only care about the bottom line
pros: Can't say that I have any - once I was hired as a full time employee my entire viewpoint of the company changed, and not for the better.
cons: CSX has been in turmoil for the past several years. Employees are constantly worried about being on the chopping block. The only reason people stick around is to get railroad retirement. They feel stuck because that is hanging over their heads. Best advice I can give to anyone there is to look elsewhere before you're removed permanently. They keep saying they're "trimming the fat," but to be frank, the company is basically anorexic now. Customers aren't happy, employees are miserable, but shareholders are pleased that their wallets feel fatter!

pros: The pride amongst CSX employees is incredible. Anywhere I go in the community, people come up to me asking how I got on at CSX and how they would love to work for us. I am proud to work for such a great company where the benefits are excellent and the people are wonderful to work with. The career opportunities are also very robust - you truly can work here forever.
cons: Given the rich history of the railroad, we still opportunity for employees who are in the various unions to feel connected to the employees in Corporate Headquarters in Jacksonville. CSX Executives are making great strides, though, and the divide gets smaller everyday.

pros: Great benefits, great pay, covers approximately 38 states with a relocation package. Its a self-contained company that offers plenty of room for a variety of career moves. Education plan with tuition assistance. You are eligible for 401K benefits from day one. Great health care plan.
cons: Nepotism is terrible. If you are a transportation employee (I.e. conductor, engineer) the discipline is terrible. Promotion to management is given to a family member over the most qualified employee.

review_title: Ok place to work, decent pay and benefits
pros: Pretty good pay and benefits, also provides education assistance.  Provides 401k, retirement, 2 weeks vacation to start, 3 weeks after 5 yrs.  If you work hard and are aggressive, they do provide good opportunity for advancement and have a good management training program for applicants hired from within.
cons: CSX comes first, family second.  You and your family needs to be aware of this and accept it.  Be prepared to be called back in to work at the drop of a hat.

pros: It is an employment situation.
cons:
Unions are in the company's pockets.
CSX has a bad habit of messing with employees payroll.
CSX randomly declines parts of employee's payroll. The employee may make a claim to rectify payroll. This can take between 2 weeks and six months for payroll to pay the arrears or they may not.
Management can be extremely hostile towards train and engine crews.
Management is  extremely authoritarian.
There is absolutely no balance between work and home or family life.
CSX views family as a Independence to their work schedule.
You will not be able to attend grandparents or friends funerals. Grandparents are not considered immediate family. 
Most management have no railroad experience.
The day you are hired they start the paper trail to hold against you whenever they feel the need to use it.
There is high amount of resentment between management and employees. Corporate inflames this unnecessarily inflame tension.

pros: Excellent benefits and retirement for anyone who sticks it out for 30 years. Railroads promote from within at least to the middle level management positions. The work is never boring and requires a broad knowledge of data and telecommunications protocols. Field technicians cover large geographical territories and work with very little supervision.
cons: In recent years using gps tracking there has been a tendency to micro manage the field forces.

pros: No Pros to working here at the moment.
cons: CEO operates like a dictator. Everyone is fearful to voice their opinions and leadership is constantly looking for internal groups to blame for every issue. Work/life balance does not exist as 12 hour days and working through you vacation time have become expected. Most groups are down to 50-60% of their staff, or worse, compared to 2016.

review_title: A company with strong leadership that is growing in the right direction.
pros: The leadership has done a tremendous job turing the company around from what was a not very diverse and transparent company to one that collaborates and celebrates successes.  Still several areas for improvement though.
cons: Career growth opportunities/promotions seemed to be all about timing and who you knew, even as a high-performer.   Mid-lever Managers were weak.  And there seemed to be a glass ceiling for women leaders/managers regarding salary/job opportunities.

pros: Pay/benefits and the retirement, if you can make it 30 years
cons: There is a contract that management agreed to and they never follow it. Not sure if I will have a job one day to the next.  The company used to be a good place to work, seemed like they cared about the workers, but HH, the new CEO is an uncaring, ego-maniac. The company netted 1.7 billion in 2016.  Apparently thats not enough, so lets change things and screw the people who made that possible.

review_title: Depends on your position and who you support
pros:
Competitive pay package for the market
Friendly management in Technology 
Fortune 500 experience 
Relevant experience for career 
Overall good people to work around
cons: New regime with a specific focus to make Wall Street happy. Short term biased view which has driven a significant amount of talent out the door - will be interesting to see who is left after his tenure is over. Some teams are working 12-16 hours a day for weeks on end, thankless job.

review_title: Feast or Famine - Some weeks you work 75 hours, others you work 20 hours.
pros: The best part of working on the railroad is the relative freedom of working outside on the road without a boss constantly breathing down your neck. Working outside can be a beautiful experience but also a miserable one depending on the weather. CSX will move trains no matter what the weather and will stick you out in it to get the job done! 100 degrees or 15 degrees, driving rain or deep snow...you will be out there. Overall it's not a bad job, but it just wasn't for me and my lifestyle. The pay was fantastic, I received FREE full benefits for a year as a new-hire, and you have the opportunity to move up to Engineer in 2-3 years depending on the need. Great job for someone out there, just not interested in breaking my back for 30 years walking on ballast in order to get Railroad Retirement.
cons:
I was on call 24 hours a day, 6 days a week with a rotating off day. This leads to ridiculous sleep schedules and never knowing when to plan personal or social events. Sometimes you would get off at 10 in the morning other days would be 8 in the evening after having worked a 12+ hour shift. I handled it for a while (I was in my early 20's) but it eventually begins to wear on you. Some weeks I would spend 4 nights in the hotel and 3 short rest periods at home. Other weeks I would only work 2 days and be off the remaining 5 days, getting paid for being available.

There is a constant battle to actually get PAID after learning MS-DOS hieroglyphic-like commands in order to enter your pay. There is also no printed "rule book" concerning pay or how to input it and asking for days off is even more difficult. You literally have to rely on word of mouth and co-workers who may or may not know how to help you with your problem(s). CSX keeps you in the dark and on a need-to-know basis concerning just about everything.

pros: CSX has one of the better benefit packages available for employees. I have been very impressed with the low cost of their health insurance, especially compared to the $450 a month package my former employer provided for a healthy family of three.
cons: As with any other job, there are some "old school" ways of thinking that have not and most likely will not change any time soon.

review_title: Used to be a great place to work
pros: Great pay, affordable benefits, company has been around a long time, stable.
cons: Now we are just a number, company does not care about their employees. Absenteeism policy for clerks just changed to 1 occurence (late or sick) for a rolling 4 weeks.  They are suspending and firing employees who have violated the policy with emergency surgeries.  Ridiculous.  I hope the EEOC and ADA get them for non compliance for people with disabilities.  Union is about useless.

pros: Competitive benefits, nice health and wellness facilities, promotes higher education, stable company if your looking to retire.
cons: Very political and unethical. HR are the worst! They enforce policies to other departments but when one of their own violates a policy they sweep it under the rug. No place for minorities if you are seeking for a leadership position.  promotions and hiring practices are based on favortism over experience and education. Very inconsistent with their policies. Bad management with a good old boy system mentality.

pros: The money, benefits, retirement are good.
cons: Upper mgmt. and yardmasters, and trainmasters do not want to put a target on their back so they pawn the blame or blame things on others or redirect the blame somewhere else. Trainmasters get into trouble for the things that upper management knows that those trainmasters have absolutely no control over. Conductors get into trouble by one trainmaster, while another trainmaster said it was ok to do that in the first place. The only reason we get paid the money we get and the benefits and the retirement is the company know that if we got paid any less we would quite after a few months. In other words it would be a revolving door.... no life at all, if your single this is the job for you. You are away from home more than you are at home,,,, very political company,

pros: I was proud that safety was atleast a very close 2nd Place to the God complex they strut around the REDI.
cons: 4 weeks into my Condoctor training at the REDI I had enough of the CSX=God Complex.
