I heard more "War" stories and In-correct material from the instructors then I heard at my VFW on Veterans Day! Get back to teaching a person to be a railroader and leave the stories for when your on the road.

pros:
Pretty good healthcare benefits
Pay was ok when you finally made it to 100% compensation
Paid holidays and usually closed up for Thanksgiving Christmas and New Years
cons: Disliked the us vs. them attitude between union and management. The work hours are difficult to adjust to since everything is based on union seniority and bid process. Some of the buildings and facilities are pretty run down and not in great parts of town ... safety on the job can be an issue.

review_title: 16 years of enjoyment as a data processing clerk, crew dispatcher. Engineers and conductors were fun to work with.
job_title: Field Clerk, Data Processing in Greenwood, SC
pros: Very DIVERSE career experience, never dull, challenging. Retirement plans awesome. Benefits good. Especially dental and eye. Training is good most of the time.
cons: Management turn over in some areas is ridiculous. Management/supervision out for blood! Benefits decrease, premiums increase, union dues increase, pay good but going down as cost goes up. Unions are not doing their jobs.

job_title: Director Labor Relations in Jacksonville, FL
pros: Teammembers who wnat to do the right thing.
cons:
Executive team wants to be precieved as a friend of all.  They do not follow their own policies or ensure those they promote adhere to policies.  Internal Politics is rampant within each department.

Will never be a great company, just a good company to work for. Unfortunately you can judge a company by out quickly people cannot wait to retire or find another job.

review_title: Work life balance is horrible for  Trainmasters,Conductors and Engineers .
pros: Pay is good after union dues,health insurance and tier 2 taxes. retirement is way better than social security if you can last the 30 years thats required for full retirement. good health insurance.
cons: Working a full 7 hours outdoors in the rain,snow,heat,cold,humidity,mud,unavoidable rain puddles. carefully walk a few miles a day over rocks over train tracks and railroad ties.20 minute lunch break. No regular sleep schedule if you work on the road 12 hours on 10 hours off 12 hours on 10 hours off.  you give up a lot of family time and you have to work most holidays.

pros: Not an office environment, decent pay
cons: Transportation department is treated like 2nd class workers.  Quality of life is non-existant, work around the clock in 12plus hr shifts.  Better have a doctors note and hope they accept it if you get sick.  Actually I could go on an on about the cons , there's a lot so I'll leave it at that.

pros: The people are friendly and helpful. I spent much of my time learning from the more experienced employees, some of which with 40+ years there. Honestly, most of the employees are about to retire so they are more than willing to transfer their knowledge to you. Furthermore, pay was great. I made pretty good money fresh out of high school. The college interns made double what I made. Awesome.
cons: At times there is a lot of down time and at others they are bombarding you with information. All in all, you were left alone which can be awkward for a new employee.

review_title: Great industry, pay and benefits, but agencies dominate leadership.
pros: Great pay and benefits. Most jobs are RR retirement, not social security. Big company footprint with opportunity to travel and move around the U.S.
cons: Due to weak leadership, department is led by multiple PR, public affairs and ad agencies instead of management team running the agencies.

pros: The non management men and women you work with on the ground.
cons: No life, layoffs, intimidating manager's, all safety rules under new ceo have been removed, the work environment is the most toxic and negative place i have ever been.

pros: Deffinatley one of the top paying jobs without a college degree. The health insurance is great. Only state employees have better health benefits around where I live. Railroad retirement is probly the best retirement plan out there and the retirement age is age 60. Easy to move around to different locations. Company is closed shop union so where you can work is based on seniorty but this can also work against you if you're new. It can be easy to get overtime here. If you want to work constantly and make money this place might be for you. Better for someone who is in their 20's, single, and has no kids. This place has a 30 year retirement so get in before you are 30 so you can collect the maximum amount of retirement at age 60.
cons: The attendance policy is overly strict. If you take any non paid time off including sick for more than 24 hours you get written up unless you have a doctor's note. The managment is always trying to write you up or threaten you so they can hold things over your head. As a new employee you will not be able to hold a job with a regular work schedule and you will have to work on call and be available 6 days a week including all holidays. They ship freight 24 hours a day 365 days a year. You will not have a regular sleep patern because of this and it will take years to hold a regular job. You only get 3 personal days as a new hire and 2 weeks vacation. One week must be taken in a block. It is very difficult to make plans around this type of lifestyle. You are subject to random drug and breathalyzer tests so there is no drinking when you are on call for work.

review_title: Overall: Good to great environment and work culture.
pros:
Work life balance is good for positions not in the field locations. (Feel a bit sorry for them though)
Many opportunities to make a difference on projects.
Leadership is approachable.
Work culture is good.
cons:
Base salary is a bit lower than some industries with the same jobs. (Could be due to Jacksonville market)
It's easier for an individual to leave their current team and get a promotion than be promoted in their current position even when exceeding expectations.

review_title: In a lot of ways this is the best company I have ever worked for.
pros: I like that we are environmentally friendly and have a pretty stable job. There are some lay offs but no where near as bad as I have seen other industries.
cons: There is too much nepotism.

pros: GOOD COMPANY OVERALL..  good pay, benefits, & RETIREMENT..
cons:
Working days, nights, weekends, & whenever is need.. On call at times...Small price to pay when it allows you to support your entire family on one salary.. Despite any bad reviews posted by others I feel very fortunate to  have had a long career in craft and management.
Its a career  & what comes with  owning it..  Some people dont want to OWN their CAREERS.. feel I DO!

review_title: If you like being threatened to be fired everyday of your career this is the job for you.
pros: Good pay, good retirement, decent health insurance. Being outdoors instead of a factory environment. Work with different people everytime.
cons: No life, can't make any plans and hope to keep them, very hard on your family and your health. Payroll steal from you and you have to watch your check like a hawk and fight for every nickel.

review_title: Good pay and benefits for an entry level position, but they come with a price
pros: Good pay, benefits, and opportunities. Lots of room for upward movement if you want it.  Can be done in a relatively short period of time.  Good relocation package and retirement can't be beat.
cons: The job is not condusive to family life.  The management training program is 6 months of living in hotels with no guarantee of placement upon completion.  Most transportation managers work about 60 hours per week.  Has a political corporate culture common in most big businesses.

review_title: CSX is a good employer. Great if you have no higher career aspirations.
pros: Great stable company. Great benefits. Very good Salary. Very solid job if you're in headquarters in Jax.
cons: Field management operates as though as in functional silos, often ignoring or being aware of the big picture while focusing on maintaining/salvaging the numbers. Office politics remind me of high school cliches, complete with cliques and factions. Promotion opportunities are often political in nature, i.e. chosen ones get interviewed as a formality while other candidates' time is wasted as filler to say they went through the proper process.

pros: This company is very safety conscious and has very good Benifits and retirement plans.
cons: You may get furloughed right out of training. The furloughs seem to last forever. The higher seniority employees can roll you off of a job you enjoy.

pros: I love what I do. Great pay/benefits. They did do a lot of extra stuff for us before coal went down, hats, shirts, tablets, cordless drill/impact set and more to show appreciation.
cons: Management is clueless. Our union is in their pocket and sells us out. Your job is always in jeopardy. You get in trouble for doing exactly what you were hired to do and do it well. You can be the most talented, hardest worker and make the same as the laziest guys.

pros: I worked side-by-side with some of the best people I've ever known.
cons: Senior leadership was weak, especially the last year Michael Ward and Clarence Gooden were there.  Gooden's behavior was unethical, and Ward didn't have the courage to fire him.  And it was an offense worthy of dismissal. Now, employees are overworked, and they cannot keep younger workers

review_title: Great place to work focused on continual improvement.
job_title: Senior Software Engineer in Jacksonville, FL
pros:
Decent Pay
Good Bonus
Good work life balance
Continually focused on improvement of company as a whole and on employee satisfaction
cons:
The focus on improvement is in the early stages, so there's lots of work to be done.
Still lots of mainframe focus.
Too many project managers.
Too many contract developers. Would probably be better off replacing some with loyal internal employees who know the business which would also reduce the need for so many project managers/app consultants.

review_title: Your nothing but a number. Company really could care less about you. Management only wants to make a name for themselves
pros: You make life long friends out here but also enemies. Most are fun to work with and make the job bearable. The pay is good and the retirement can't be beat. But don't let the railroad fool you into thinking they make that happen. That's your Union at work for you. You also get to see and do things here you never would have had the opportunity to before. Pay could be better compared to other railroads but overall not bad. The experience you gain is great as well.
cons: Too many to list but I'll try! 1. Management does not really care for you. Only what they can do to make themselves look good. Most of the management are straight out of college with no experience in railroading however expect you to respect their authority and like to think they know how the railroad operates when in truth they are clueless. 2. They are out to fire you. Why would that be you may ask? Let me outline it for you. The government pays them subsidies for hiring the American worker. They then train you and make you believe you have just started a wonderful career and that you will be here for a very long time. Neglecting to tell you that most likely you will be furloughed the first day you are done with your training. You could be furloughed up to a full year and all the while CSX has made money off the government while you sit around hoping to get called again. They pretty much bank on the fact that you most likely will not return. This however helps them look good to the public and their shareholders for all PR purposes to look like they are helping the Economy and hiring people. It makes it look like they  are doing so much business that they have to hire new people. The management is actually told to write people up. That they have written the rule books so that there is no way that the employee can ever be 100 percent rule compliant. 3. Your family life will be non existent. The divorce rate on the railroad is through the roof. Since joining the railroad it has been a struggle just to keep my marriage afloat. My son hates me and my daughter cries all the time because I'm never Home! I've missed two thanksgivings and one Christmas so far. I've missed my anniversary 4 times and all of my sons ball games. This company does nothing to help you on this matter and could care less. Again you are nothing but a number. The only reason people stay here is for the retirement. The railroad is nothing like what it use to be. It's only about the dollar. Corporate greed at its finest with CSX. This year, we have been told that due to Hurricane Isaac we will not be getting our yearly bonus, however Mr. Micheal Ward, the company CEO got his bonus of over 9 million dollars. Way to care about your employees Mr. Ward. Again There are entirely too many to list here but i can assure you that the cons FAR outweigh the pros You have to ask yourself whats important in you life and if you are ready to sacrifice all that for a bunch of empty promises. I'm only still here because the job market in this area is horrible and this is whats paying the bills

pros: The pay and great benefits the company has to offer are good they also offer health and wellness program. This is a long term career path lots of growth opportunity with this company. The people you work with are like a family try to watch out for one another. Opportunity to travel see other places. offer a safety bonus for your first two years and a stock option for never missing work and demand day off every 90 days. 2 weeks vacation and 10 personal days after your first year.
cons: Some of the challenges with this company is that it is a economy driven business. Its hard to keep working your first few years in some locations. So many rules that are always changing hard to keep up with. Always seem to run trains at night not the day so its hard to get use to trying to find out when to rest. Never really know when you might get called. Got to live by the phone. Good words to live by, Safety first double check everything. Never get in a hurry. Always be ready and stay ready just when you think your not going to get called your phone will ring to come to work.

review_title: Dynamic company really trying to make a difference
pros: Executive management (CEO, CFO, CIO, etc.) is absolutely, without exception, top notch.  Great benefits, flexible time off policies, the best co-workers I've ever had, good PC work environment
cons: More meetings than productivity, advancement gridlock, inconsistent performance management, self-promotion is rewarded while production receives more work. Many long-timers are completely complacent and snarl at the suggestion of change. Employees are behind in technology knowledge (more snarling) and scoff at the knowledge of younger peers.

review_title: Great Company, but set in their ways
pros: Great leadership team.  Focus on safety.   They expect you to work hard and reward you for doing a good job.   Good pay, great bonus (when we earn it - most years), decent benefits.    Some real good leaders in the company.    You are often given a lot of latitude to do the job.   Do well and it is recognized.
cons: Work in silos.  Benefits could be better.   Downtown charges employees for parking.   Company has started to improve employee perks but could do a lot better.

review_title: Locomotive Engineers and Conductors have great pay but your family and personal life will suffer extensively.
pros: Pay and healthcare plan is well above average.  Railroad Retirement pension is very good as well if you can last that long. You have Union representation and you will need it!
cons: In the Transportation Department, you will have many obstacles during your career.  Some come with the job because of the 24/7 service requirements.  Let's face it, about 2/3 of the U.S. economy travels by rail.  Management will provide the rest of the problems. First, though pay is very good in the end, you will spend a great deal of time with payroll, labor relations and your union rep trying to get properly paid for your work. The carrier does not honor agreed work rules and accurate payroll is a constant struggle. Second, due to the management structure you are treated as the enemy not a team member by local and middle management. Almost all infractions carry suspension time from seven to thirty days. You are offered "job insurance" that will help you pay bills while you miss work after being disciplined. Only job I know of where this is needed.  You arrive everyday wondering if you will have a job when you get off because when ANYTHING goes wrong, accountability ends with you. Management is almost never responsible for mistakes.  The attitude is basically, "How can we put this on the transportation employee?" CSX has thousands of work rules that are engineered to be impossible to follow at a 100% level. This way local management can intimidate you to speed up to unsafe levels in order to meet their performance numbers and easily punish you when you fail or refuse to put their production requirements ahead of safety. The Union tries to fight this daily but the reality is that Railroad Unions have very little power or influence anymore. Third, your life will revolve around the railroad. You will work almost all holidays, nights, weekends, birthdays, etc., etc. Attendance policy is barbaric at best as absence is only excused by way of Urgent care facility or Hospital Emergency room. Literally! Almost everyone in this department has divorced at least once and the lack of schedule will eliminate any possibility of child custody.  You will struggle to spend time with family and friends even if you are able to hold things together throughout your career. Your fellow employees will be your family and friends because they are the only ones who will understand.

review_title: Love Csx but not the politcs
pros: Pay, benefits, hard working  people
cons: Work/life balance don't  really  exists

pros: fun, easy job. you get to see places you normally wouldnt from a one of a kind perspective. if you like to travel it is a lot of fun and the work is not hard at all.
cons: the hours are rough being on call 24/7. it is difficult on relationships because sometimes you have to leave in the middle of dinner or during a movie.

job_title: Freight Conductor in Fort Wayne, IN
pros: Pay is good when working, very enjoyable job to have and not the exact same every time out. When hired a school is required to teach the basics.....very good course.
cons: Upper management talks a good game on we care about our employees, but the fire breathing dragon rears it's head regularly to layoff hundreds at a time before Xmas every year till mid to late spring. The huge unspoken word of the company is LOYALTY....almost a sin to mention.

pros: I really don't know anymore
cons: Work in all weather condions.  Work on confined unsanitary locomotives and stay in dirty hotels but we get no sick days.  We get Holiday pay only if on regular jobs but will take away one of your personal days for it.   Can't ever schedule a personal leave day or daily vacation because the caps are set at least 8 times lower then the number of days workers have.  One of the lowest paid on call,  no structure,  living in hotels jobs out there.  Divorce rate is very high if you work for the railroad.

pros: CSX offers a fair salary - and excellent benefits (including railroad retirement).  The leadership at the top of the company is excellent - and in recent years cash bonuses have been sizeable.   Engineering Department is well ran and resources for our work have been growing.
cons: Those in the Operations department work long and unpredictable hours.  Physical positions can be demanding.  Opportunities for promotion are limited in some departments, and there are some examples of people doing the same job with different titles (and different salaries)

pros: CSX has a strong people focus culture, putting people first has allowed leadership to ensure our place as one of the best places to work in the industry; I've had several different types of positions (different careers if you will) while staying at one company; Working in Talent Acquisition allows me to ensure CSX is getting the best future employees available.
cons: Our industry is 24x7 and there are times when that lifestyle can be difficult to maintain; While we don't have overtime compensation for management employees, we have a performance based bonus program that compensates for the long hours.

review_title: Run away, don't walk and don't look back
pros: Pay, benefits, railroad retirement, coworkers are big pros but that's about it.
cons: They're always trying to fire you for anything and everything, work/life balance is terrible, always on call until you have the seniority to hold a "scheduled" job but can be bumped by a senior employee anytime, frequent furloughs, weak union, poor morale, ungrateful management, you pretty much have to call in sick  just to get a day off.

review_title: I've been working on the railroad, all the live long day
job_title: Locomotive Engineer in Clifton Forge, VA
pros: Fairly decent pay and benefits. I say fairly because if you start dividing hours involved into the money made, it not as good as it may look at first.
cons:
I'm not sure there is enough room on this page. If you read through all the reviews for CSX on Glassdoor, you will notice a definate pattern. Those who work in an office type environment or regular hours (Mon-Fri, 8 hrs a day)  tend to have a favorable opinion of the CSX. Those who work  in the Transportation Department  -T&E (Trainmen and Engineers), as I do, almost always have a poor opinion of CSX. 
 At any rate I've been with CSX for 10+  years. I have never in my life worked for a company where there is so much animosity between management  and the frontline labor force. It is definately a hostile, them against us environment. These flames are fanned on a regular basis by poorly qualified low and mid level managers.
 The hours are long and unpredictable. 12 hour days are not uncommon and you will most likely be on call 24 hrs per day. With the exception of yard jobs, you will seldom go to, or get off work at the same time. You may get called at 23:00 and be expected to work till 11:00 the next morning.  The next time you may be called to work 11:00 until 23:00.  It is a NEVER ENDING case of jet lag. Depending on the job, you will likely get 1 day off per week or 2 days off every other week. It is unlikely that your day or days off will include a Saturday or Sunday.  Again unless you are working a yard job, there is no such thing as a holiday.  Trainmen (Conductor) and Engineer jobs are seldom beneficial to ones health or relationships (spouse, family and friends). You may think that all that travel and rail riding sounds fun and exciting, but going back and forth between the same points over and over quickly becomes monotonous/tedious.  
I could go on with detail after detail about the "cons" but I think you may be getting my point. Over all if you are considering a job with CSX, look for one with regular hours and days off in a department other than Transportation. Avoid Conductor and Engineer jobs.

pros: Good benefits and pay for Jacksonville.  The Pension and RR Retirement for long term employees are great benefits, although they are not as good for the new hires as they once were.
cons: Company has been reducing headcount for years.  The latest cuts place more of a burden on employees.  Current environment is one of fear to lose your job.  This isn't the family atmosphere that was there years ago when I started.

pros: Good pay, Good benefits, hard to beat for people without an education.
cons: You are a number to the company, not a person with a family and bills to pay. You wont get a pat on the back for doing a good job, but many slaps on the wrist if you don't meet times/numbers they would like. Management vs. Everyone else.

review_title: Changed in the short time I've been here
pros:
Great benefits, probably the best you'll find. 
Welcomed changes to vacation structure.
cons:
Good ole boy mentality, favoritism runs rampant. 
Great disconnect between what happens in the field and at HQ, weaknesses in internal communications. 
Annual pay increases should be earned and not expected.

review_title: I now understand the old saying " I got Railroaded"
pros: Compensation, Health care, and and retirement are all good. The work is not very phyisically demanding and the job itself is usually exciting and different every day.
cons:
No set schedule make's it very hard to plan even a day ahead of time though that isn't as much CSX's fault as it is the nature of the industry. Most management employee's are hired out of college and have no understanding of what it actually takes to make things happen. They have no railroad experiance and they are taught to feel superior to craft employees. They try to force un-realistic policies and practices into place that hurt production, customer, and employee satisfaction. Employees are required to carry 5+ rule books at all times and penalties for even minor diviations from the book* are blown completely out of proportion. Rules are subject to interpritation and what is acceptable to one manager may not be to the next so your never comfortable with what your doing and spend more time worried about wether or not a manager is watching you with night vision than about doing your job and staying alive. They preach safety, accountability, and wellness, but only if it dosn't actually require them to do anything or spend a couple of dollars. 

* Employees have recieved time off for walking to fast, standing with their hands in their pockets, not saying over or out on the radio, taking safety glasses off momentarly because they had fogged up, and many many other petty violations.

pros: Good pay for the what you do. Great benefits for you and your family. A good bunch of people to work WITH.
cons: on call 24/7, you really cant make plans. hard to get time off. Management hiding in the bushes watching you, waiting for you to do something wrong so they can charge/fire you

pros: I enjoy ensuring the economy moves in the right direction. The freedom to work without being looked over the shoulder everyday. The training that I received in order to do my job safely. The benefits. The pay. The customers.
cons: The hotel is your home. Work life balance is available for Senior Management, H.R. and Labor Relations.  Work life balance is not available for Lower Management or their direct repots (the true face of the company). Labor relations don't understand the contract they signed when it relates to paying what was agreed upon. If they can take the money back due to something in the contract they understand it clearly, if you dont understand it then too bad. Opportunity is not always given to the best candidates rather to friends and family referrals. No diversity. Most accountability standards only pertain to train crews. Intimidation is used often even if it requires breaking a rule or is unsafe. The last two examples means that this place is unethical. Unethical activities need not be reported, they will to be placed on a desk and lost rather than resolved if it come from union employee unless an attorney is involved.

pros: Pay when you work, free insurance for one year.
cons: CSX will hire too many people, then cut you off from assignment due to the lack of work and over populated terminals. Be looking for another job at all times. Manager are there to ensure you are doing your job at all times, so you will be tested by them breaking the rules that they tell you to follow.

review_title: Once great company to work for on a downhill spiral under new management.
pros:
Ok pay (when bonus is counted)
Still good people left in company
Room to grow since so many people have been eliminated
cons:
CEO and new management 
Lack of communication
Fear of retaliation if disagree with new ideas
Too much focus on shareholders
Low employee morale
Corporate greed

review_title: Intelligent, motivated people with a complex project making a difference in people’s lives over time.
pros: My coworkers were intelligent, diverse, hard-working.  We respected each other’s strengths and readily helped each other with tasks and projects. The company culture focused a lot on employee safety, which made me feel valued and also accountable to those I worked with.
cons: So much to do, staying late often felt necessary to be able to keep up. Might say more about my personality than the company, since only one other person on my team did this as much as I did.

job_title: Locomotive Engineer and Conductor in Birmingham, AL
pros: Learn great skills. Get to travel.
cons: No time to enjoy life, Just as quick to fire you as fast as they hired you. Even though its a Union job, Unions has no power because they are bought out and at the mercy of the Facist Company.  Many accidents have happened due too fatigue because of working long 12 to 15 hour days 6 days a week. Every year you get a 3% raise thats wiped out by the union increased fees and healthcare increase.

pros: Good bonuses typically, but you'll earn every penny with your blood sweat and tears
cons: With the new leadership in place you might as well be working for the mafia. The environment is soul draining and ruthless. They expect 60+ hours of work/week and are looking at headcount everyday, so basically you're competing for your job on a daily basis. Management is out for themselves and could care less about the growth and advancement of their employees. People who advance are done so based and brown nosing and climbing over others, not on skill or experience. So you better put up and shut up. If this is your thing than you'll be a good fit.

review_title: Rail Sales and Marketing Position Seekers
pros: salary and benefits are tough to beat; you will work with some of the greatest people and learn a lot
cons: goals oriented with little input from your supervisor; if you are not able to build a network internally, then you will not make it.

pros: the pay was good and the work was easy once you learned all the rules and some pretty cool discounts
cons: its based on seniority and you can be furloughed when it get slow the union really doesn't do anything for you either and you have to be in it

review_title: Hard work for the pay, don't look for a pat on the back
pros: pay is good if you don't mind working outside in all weather, benefits are very good and union membership is available.
cons: work in harsh weather, seniority based so salary and jobs available will not be that great starting out, not a feel good company, the harsh work environment is par for the course

review_title: Stable & pay is slightly above average, but they get their money's worth & then some from you.
pros:
Fortune 500
Fairly stable
Prestige of big company
cons:
Opportunities for advancement within are not good
Stable almost to the point of stagnation
Not all senior level management behave like people make the difference.

review_title: Excellent pay, but for the most part you are treated as disposable.
job_title: Independent Signal Maintainer in Toledo, OH
pros: Excellent pay, decent union backing, decent benifits, you pay into railroad retirement instead of social security, your wife gets a retirement also.
cons: Poor management, bad work life balance, most employees have a poor outlook on life, relocation seems to be inevitable so dont plan on settling down.

review_title: I've been working on the Railroad!
pros: Great pay and good benefits. Was a very interesting job in the fact that you drive trains. Got to enjoy the outdoors
cons: Horrible management. Once they hire you, they try to fire you by constantly hiding in the bushes (literally) to find you breaking one of the 300+ rules. Often denying valid claims for pay.

review_title: Company is going into the tank!
pros: Great craft people, good pay.
cons: Pressure from upper management that have no clue what it takes to get the work done. They pressure lower managers to get numbers that are not realistic and some fudge the numbers to meet these expectations.

review_title: Good Place Except they cut your job
pros: Good pay. Not too busy. Friendly people. Benefits are OK. Safety is very important to them - which is important to me because I want others to be safe so I do not die because of their carelessness.
cons: They cut jobs. The motto is 'hurry up and wait' because you're bored most of the time. If you're a parent, you WILL miss much of your children's lives.

pros: Pay and Benefits yearly raise
cons: Never knowing if you will be furloughed from one week to the next. I have worked on call and rarely seen my family for the last eight years . DONT WASTE YOUR TIME CSX IS NOT THE JOB IT WAS IN THE PAST! Living in limbo of will you stand for a job from week to week able to provide for your family, all the while getting called out on your rest exhausted daily working your butt off.  CSX sucks the life out of you and gives nothing in return. Happy Holidays!!

review_title: In the beginning nepotism ruled, in the end its still about who you know and not about performance to move up at CSX
pros: The best thing about working there is there are plenty of opportunities to advance
cons: The bad thing is you won't advance based on performance.

pros: Health Benefits and salaries are excellent. You get to travel, you get the opportunity to learn the transportation by train business. You also have the opportunity to advance through the ranks.
cons: Seasoned employees don't take time to help you, could be more helpful when you are in your training stages of the job.

pros: Over 20 years of service now contract employees are worthless.
cons: They find any reason to fire you. I hate my job, it's now a poisonous fear environment. I'm constantly  threaten about job  performance. Csx have cut jobs with less people and with less time to do the job they want more work done.

pros: If you make it to retirement, Csx has a good retirement plan.
cons: Built up expectation only for a let down (don’t make as much money as they say you will!) , crew callers are so rude and inconsiderate (clearly from lack of training), crew callers call for job even though you aren’t on that  job (felt like I constantly had to play the game), management is trained to fire you, Cleveland is a young terminal so seniority will not grow for a lot of years - so good luck not being laid off!  My advice is don’t waste your time and find a company that cares about its employees.

pros:
-Very good health benefits
-Very good retirement plan
-Locally, the company offers some of the best salaries (not nationally)
-Value diversity
-Nearly 50% of the workforce is eligible for retirment, so opportunities for growth are coming....EVENTUALLY
cons:
-Nearly 50% of the workforce is eligible for retirement, so there is a large gap in culture among employees
-Depending on where you start with the company, your opportunities for advancement may be stifled becuase of the flat structure of the organization.

review_title: Good if your in the right department
pros:
Good benefits
Most departments are very good to work for/with
Job Security
cons:
A lot of internal empire building
In order to advance, you have to be chosen by executive management as worthy to sit at the table.
Lack of communication by executive management
If you don't fit the model of what they are looking for, life will be difficult.

pros: Excellent training, excellent benefits. There is good opportunity for advancement. Very large senority district to move around.
cons: Training pay is not that great, $600/wk with no overtime. Working 12 hour days 6 days a week. Right after being hired and qualifying, trainees are being furloughed.

review_title: If money is the only reason you wake up in the morning.. this might be for you
pros: Compensation and benefits.. railroad retirement is second to none.  This section has a minimum of twenty words.. and I don't have much else to say that's positive.. unless you really like trains, rain, and snow.
cons: Zero quality of life.  The schedule allows for no planning of social functions, or even doctors appointments.  With a new attendance policy enacted (3/15), you are penalized for sick days.. even with valid documentation from your physician.

pros: I worked for CSX for 4 years in several different roles pay is great but you work a lot and arent home that often.
cons: Work on Call and are away from family to much. Talk about living a healthy lifestyle but the job doesn't allow for this is the crazy scheduling.

review_title: New CEO Destroying a Once-Strong Company
pros: Competitive pay, good benefits, interesting/challenging work.
cons: New CEO making severe cuts, often eliminating very talented and experienced employees, seemingly for no reason at all. He's instilling a culture of fear and intimidation that makes it a miserable place to work. No one is safe from the chopping block, except EHH and the people he brought with him.

pros: This WAS a good company to work for.  Challenging work.  All equipment supplied by company.  Salary gauged in the 50th percentile among Fortune 500 companies.  A great deal of freedom in movement by nature of the job.
cons: Management bonus is subject to issues beyond personal control.  No seniority consideration.  One-size-fits-all corporate decision making.

pros:
-Good pension, the craft workers do not pay into social security.
-Tuition Reimbursement, other good benefits
-Good pay compared to similar jobs outside the railroad
cons:
-Some crafts require forced overtime
-company seems to be in a time of transition, layoffs, etc. 
-Some crafts get very little time off, and spend a lot of time away from home. 
-only management receives 401k matching

review_title: Challenging and rewarding, but a different lifestyle than most.
pros: The management benefits and entry wage rates are competitive, and the retirement is excellent. There are a wide range of career paths available within the company.
cons: The field operations management positions have little support, and very long, unconventional hours which makes the work/ Life ballance very difficult to successfully manage.

pros: Good pay for kids right out of school. If you have professional experience the job pay is okay. Good ability to advance if people actually retire
cons: You will work well over 60 hr weeks and will be judged poorly if you leave early. You get talked to like you are a Marine private by some of the management

pros: Doing something different every day, good people to work with. Have to use critical thinking skills in some situations. A good safe work environment.
cons: Not enough spots for new hires on extra board. I believe they need to go to the bid system so new hires are not sitting at home all the time waiting to get called for work. A lot of complainers that need to be thankful for having a job.

pros: Depending on if you fit in with the culture, you can skyrocket quickly.
cons: If for any reason you are not in lock-step with the culture, don't expect career progression.  If you work in Finance, expect to be overworked by your boss and "business partners" while underpaid and insulted constantly, and watch the golden employees get promoted quickly.

review_title: Stable company with long term vision. Better benefits compared to other companies.

review_title: Not the best, yet not the worst
job_title: Band V Manager in Jacksonville, FL

cons: They work you to no end. The railroad always comes first for field managers. They like to hire a lot straight out of college. Very tough for those who have never worked like this before.

pros: Great pay and benefits for train and engine service

review_title: great for 7 years-  new management came in and it all went to .............

cons: no matter what work you perform, how well you do- others dont and it really is not addressed- dont know whats going on there but its going downhill fast- esp in intermodal

pros: Great pay-teammates are supportive-career development is valued- input is thoughtfully considered-flexible hours and time off-good exposure and lots of opportunity

pros: Great people to work with.

No work/life balance for managers.  If you don't write up enough T&E employees you are putting your job on the line.  You only get promoted if you will move at the drop of a hat AND are in a certain click.

Biggest Con of all: Cindy Sanborn, Cindy Sanborn, Cindy Sanborn

pros: Retirement, Bonuses, Pay, Employees, Not being in an office environment, Learn something new every day

job_title: Locomotive Engineer in Fort Wayne, IN

Excellent earnings potential

review_title: Not bad but could be better

review_title: Not a good place to work

Constant cuts and layoffs are the norm so don't expect any real job security. Every new contract is worse than the last, meaning that health insurance costs and copays rise with every contract, while wages remain stagnant.

pros: Overall, I enjoy the work and the company of my team. The people are friendly and the industry is only going to grow.
cons: There is a large generation gap that exists between new hires and the veterans. Although this often sold to new hires as a fast track, it may not necessarily be.

pros: Great money! Great retirement! Room for advancement if you keep a great attendence and safety record.

pros: Diverse envrionment; not relating this to race or national orgin but the fact that so many individuals in my department have diverse academic backgrounds who are able to bring a multitude of ideas to the table.

review_title: So much time is spent training to be a good safe worker.  After that, the rest of your career you try no to get fired.

cons: Hostile work environment. May be on call 24-7. 2 hours to report to work when called. Hard on one social life, family, friends, etc. Management seems more interested in aggressive discipline than employee development.

I think they should want there employees to stay out of trouble and do good work, instead they scare them into not wanting to go above and beyond. ....

review_title: One of the most respected employers in Jacksonville
pros: Great opportunities for high performers to move to different roles around the company to learn and gain difference experiences. Solid pay, especially when factoring in bonus and benefits. Collegial environment; a lot of really wonderful people to work with.
cons: As a railroad, operations experience is sometimes valued above other critical leadership skills. As a result, there are not very many women in leadership positions beyond the Director level.

job_title: Several Positions Craft/Management in Atlanta, GA
pros:
Strong Safety Culture
Job Satisfaction 
Unique Work Environments
Career Opportunity
Development Opportunity
Great Benefits
Competitive Salary
cons:
Working in a craft position can be an adjustment for someone who may be unfamiliar with working under a collective bargaining agreement.

Some managers have no idea whats going on. Little time with family.  No social life if you cared to have one.  Likes to poke employees with pitch forks when irritated.

review_title: Not as good as it once was, but still good.
pros: CSX has had some changes due to realignment lately but overall remains a solid company to work for. Benefits are at least equal to industry standards. Upward mobility possible in the right department, promotions generally come from within.
cons: Some positions require a lot of hours, especially those in Transportation. Recent shake-ups give pause to long-term reliability as an employer.

pros: The Pay (mangers have no idea of how to operate trains) CSX is run by #s (which are faked per onboard) and run by a hedge fund not railroaders who’s only goal is to cut costs and make each quarter more profitable. Historically and common sense railroads don’t sell there lines....... like funny joke did you ever sell your railroads in monopoly 🤔 NO you mortgaged them but never ever sold them the people running this comsnpny  Lacks the experience or knowledge to run a railroad. Instead they are running a numbers games and that’s why it’s failing.
cons: You’re a #, helping the company isn’t rewarded, you’re the first to blame, doing your job right “delay of train, doing your job wrong rule violation” either way every day is a constant attempt by mangers to fire you catch you doing a rule wrong (which they change the rules it seems like monthly now) nothing todo with railroading just CYA for them so you can’t sue them ex- “clear of all tracks” “place of safety” “point from the ground” 🙄 three ways to say the same thing that has changed over the past 3 years......  The real sticker now with the company is man power shortages and cover ups of their actual numbers “dwell times and such” forcing conductors to lie daily on the onboard to fix there numbers so middle management doesn’t get yelled at..... just try and say you aren’t going to lie on the on board and recently the company’s new displace policy includes “ insubordination “ which CSX mangers can use for anything they please. Contractually naps were included in our line of work to help with exhausted conductors/engineers stuck in a spot not moving (trains block trains a lot) to allow them to catch up on rest and be ready to go when they can that’s a thing of the past 🤔 which you’ll get charged a major rule violation now for napping on the job even if you’re stuck in a spot for 3+ hours due to dispatching widows something tottaly uncontrollable and nothing todo with you. (Ninja Trainmaster love sneaking up on you and make sure you’re awake and just sitting there staring into space) The company recently in its never ending attempt to make working for them a living hell has decided to force either an engineer or conductor to show up and sit for 8 hours at the office when they don’t have an engineer or conductor to fill the two man crew agreement. Example for Christmas Eve your engineer is off on a vacation day and you show up to work and required to sit and do nothing for 8 hours (btw don’t sleep that’s a no no) (don’t play on your phone either it’s “unauthorized use of a personal cellar device” ) CSX refuses to Annul jobs when one crew member isn’t a single to work either because they are fixing their number or just making their employees come to work and sit because they can. I’m actually shocked at why I pay union dues I think the unions should have striked  a long time ago....

pros: The pay is pretty good. Other than that read the Cons.

The UTU union will not help you if you need something even though you pay a $100 month union due. Management literally hides in the bushes and waits for you to slip up and doesn't think twice about firing you. Want to take a lunch? Forget that.
